subject: Productivity
title: Frederick Taylor and Scientific Management
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Frederick Taylor and Scientific Management.

hook.text: Frederick Taylor stood in a steel mill with a stopwatch, timing every shovel of coal.

buildup.text: In the 1880s, Taylor broke factory work into timed tasks. He called it scientific management.

discovery.text: By optimizing each motion, Bethlehem Steel's output tripled. Efficiency became a science.

twist.text: Workers hated it. Taylor treated humans like machines. Labor unions called it dehumanizing.

climax.text: Taylor's ideas still shape modern workplaces. Performance metrics descend directly from his stopwatch.

punchline.text: The stopwatch changed work forever ‚Äî for better and worse.

quiz.question: What did Frederick Taylor call his approach to optimizing work?
